Article.ArticleTitle: Interfacial vs Bulk Ozonolysis of Nerolidol.

AbstractText: Ozone readily reacts with olefins with the formation of more reactive Criegee intermediates (CIs). The transient CIs impact HO <sub>x</sub> cycles, and they play a role in new particle formation in the troposphere. Oxidation by O<sub>3</sub> occurs both in the gas-phase, in the liquid phase, and at air-water and air-aerosol interfaces. In light of the importance of O<sub>3</sub> in environmental and engineered chemical transformations, we have investigated the ozonolysis mechanisms of a triolefin C<sub>15</sub>-alcohol, nerolidol (Nero, a biogenic sesquiterpene), at the air-water interface in the presence of acetonitrile. Surface-sensitive pneumatic ionization mass spectrometric detection of α-hydroxy-hydroperoxides and functionalized carboxylates, generated by the hydration and isomerization of CIs, respectively, enables us to evaluate the relative reactivity of each C=C toward O<sub>3</sub>. In addition, we compare bulk-phase ozonolysis chemistry to similar reactions taking place at the air-water interface. Our experimental results show that O<sub>3</sub> reacts primarily with the (CH<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>C=CH- and -(CH<sub>3</sub>)C=CH- moieties (>∼98%), while the O<sub>3</sub> attack on the terminal -HC=CH<sub>2</sub> site (<∼2%) is a minor pathway during both interfacial and bulk ozonolysis. The presence of functionalized-carboxylates on interfaces but not in bulk-phase reactions with O<sub>3</sub> indicates that the isomerization of the CIs is not hindered at the air-water interface due to the lower availability of water .
